1‚Üí# midisnoop
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíA CLI tool for **passive monitoring** of all CoreMIDI traffic on macOS - spy on MIDI conversations between devices without rewiring them.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí## Features
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Passive monitoring of MIDI sources (inputs)** - works out of the box
     8‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Passive monitoring of MIDI destinations (outputs)** - built-in SnoizeMIDISpy driver
     9‚Üí- ‚úÖ **No rewiring required** - monitors existing MIDI connections transparently
    10‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Color-coded output** - green for sources, blue for destinations
    11‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Decodes MIDI messages** - shows message types and channel info
    12‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Hex dump** - displays raw MIDI bytes
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí## Quick Start
    15‚Üí
    16‚Üí\```bash
    17‚Üímake build          # Build midisnoop and SnoizeMIDISpy driver
    18‚Üímake install-driver # Install driver to ~/Library/Audio/MIDI Drivers
    19‚Üímake run            # Run midisnoop
    20‚Üí\```
    21‚Üí
    22‚ÜíThe first time you run `midisnoop`, it will automatically install the SnoizeMIDISpy driver if needed.
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí## How It Works
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí### Source Monitoring (Always Available)
    27‚Üímidisnoop connects to all MIDI sources using standard CoreMIDI APIs:
    28‚Üí- `MIDIInputPortCreate()` creates an input port
    29‚Üí- `MIDIPortConnectSource()` connects to each source
    30‚Üí- Callbacks receive MIDI packets passively
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí### Destination Monitoring (Built-in Driver)
    33‚ÜíPassive destination monitoring requires a CoreMIDI driver plugin that intercepts system-level MIDI traffic:
    34‚Üí- The **SpyingMIDIDriver** implements the `MIDIDriverInterface` with a `Monitor` callback
    35‚Üí- The driver calls `MIDIDriverEnableMonitoring(true)` to receive ALL outgoing MIDI packets
    36‚Üí- CoreMIDI server routes packets to the driver transparently
    37‚Üí- The driver broadcasts packets to midisnoop via message ports
    38‚Üí- **No rewiring required** - existing MIDI connections work normally
    39‚Üí
    40‚ÜíThis project includes a build of the open-source [SnoizeMIDISpy driver](https://github.com/krevis/MIDIApps) from MIDI Monitor.
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí## Output Format
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí\```
    45‚Üí[SOURCE] m4-mini : Note On (ch 1) : 90 3C 7F
    46‚Üí[SOURCE] Launch Control XL : Control Change (ch 1) : B0 0D 42
    47‚Üí[DESTINATION] DAW In : Note Off (ch 1) : 80 3C 00
    48‚Üí\```
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí## Build Commands
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí\```bash
    53‚Üímake build          # Compile midisnoop and driver
    54‚Üímake install-driver # Install driver to ~/Library/Audio/MIDI Drivers
    55‚Üímake run            # Build and run
    56‚Üímake clean          # Remove build artifacts
    57‚Üímake help           # Show all targets
    58‚Üí\```
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí## Project Structure
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí\```
    63‚Üímidi-snoop/
    64‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ midisnoop.mm              # Main CLI application
    65‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ snoize-spy/               # SnoizeMIDISpy driver and framework
    66‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ driver/               # CoreMIDI driver plugin sources

    25‚Üí// Simple JSON builder for responses
    26‚Üíclass JsonBuilder
    27‚Üí{
    28‚Üípublic:
    29‚Üí    JsonBuilder& startObject() { ss << "{"; firstItem = true; return *this; }
    30‚Üí    JsonBuilder& endObject() { ss << "}"; return *this; }
    31‚Üí    JsonBuilder& startArray() { ss << "["; firstItem = true; return *this; }
    32‚Üí    JsonBuilder& endArray() { ss << "]"; return *this; }
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí    JsonBuilder& key(const std::string& k) {
    35‚Üí        if (!firstItem) ss << ",";
    36‚Üí        ss << "\"" << k << "\":";
    37‚Üí        firstItem = false;
    38‚Üí        return *this;
    39‚Üí    }
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí    JsonBuilder& value(const std::string& v) {
    42‚Üí        ss << "\"" << v << "\"";
    43‚Üí        return *this;
    44‚Üí    }
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí    JsonBuilder& value(bool b) {
    47‚Üí        ss << (b ? "true" : "false");
    48‚Üí        return *this;
    49‚Üí    }
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí    JsonBuilder& value(int i) {
    52‚Üí        ss << i;
    53‚Üí        return *this;
    54‚Üí    }
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí    JsonBuilder& arrayValue(const std::string& v) {
    57‚Üí        if (!firstItem) ss << ",";
    58‚Üí        ss << "\"" << v << "\"";
    59‚Üí        firstItem = false;
    60‚Üí        return *this;
    61‚Üí    }
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí    JsonBuilder& arrayValue(int i) {
    64‚Üí        if (!firstItem) ss << ",";
    65‚Üí        ss << i;
    66‚Üí        firstItem = false;
    67‚Üí        return *this;
    68‚Üí    }
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí    std::string toString() { return ss.str(); }
    71‚Üí
    72‚Üíprivate:
    73‚Üí    std::stringstream ss;
    74‚Üí    bool firstItem = true;
    75‚Üí};

    77‚Üí//==============================================================================
    78‚Üí// MIDI Port wrapper with message queuing
    79‚Üíclass MidiPort : public juce::MidiInputCallback
    80‚Üí{
    81‚Üípublic:
    82‚Üí    MidiPort(const std::string& id, const std::string& name, bool isInput)
    83‚Üí        : portId(id), portName(name), isInputPort(isInput) {}
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí    ~MidiPort() override { close(); }
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí    bool open() {
    88‚Üí        if (isInputPort) {
    89‚Üí            auto devices = juce::MidiInput::getAvailableDevices();
    90‚Üí            for (const auto& device : devices) {
    91‚Üí                if (device.name.toStdString().find(portName) != std::string::npos) {
    92‚Üí                    input = juce::MidiInput::openDevice(device.identifier, this);
    93‚Üí                    if (input) {
    94‚Üí                        input->start();
    95‚Üí                        return true;
    96‚Üí                    }
    97‚Üí                }
    98‚Üí            }
    99‚Üí        } else {
   100‚Üí            auto devices = juce::MidiOutput::getAvailableDevices();
   101‚Üí            for (const auto& device : devices) {
   102‚Üí                if (device.name.toStdString().find(portName) != std::string::npos) {
   103‚Üí                    output = juce::MidiOutput::openDevice(device.identifier);
   104‚Üí                    return output != nullptr;
   105‚Üí                }
   106‚Üí            }
   107‚Üí        }
   108‚Üí        return false;
   109‚Üí    }
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí    void close() {
   112‚Üí        if (input) {
   113‚Üí            input->stop();
   114‚Üí            input.reset();
   115‚Üí        }
   116‚Üí        output.reset();
   117‚Üí    }
   118‚Üí
   119‚Üí    void sendMessage(const std::vector<uint8_t>& data) {
   120‚Üí        if (!output) return;
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí        // Validate message has data
   123‚Üí        if (data.empty()) {
   124‚Üí            std::cerr << "Warning: Attempted to send empty MIDI message\n";
   125‚Üí            return;
   126‚Üí        }
   127‚Üí
   128‚Üí        if (data[0] == 0xF0) {
   129‚Üí            // For SysEx messages, validate they end with 0xF7
   130‚Üí            if (data.back() != 0xF7) {
   131‚Üí                std::cerr << "Warning: Invalid SysEx message (missing 0xF7)\n";
   132‚Üí                return;
   133‚Üí            }
   134‚Üí
   135‚Üí            // createSysExMessage expects the data WITHOUT F0/F7 wrappers
   136‚Üí            // So we need to pass just the middle part
   137‚Üí            if (data.size() > 2) {
   138‚Üí                output->sendMessageNow(
   139‚Üí                    juce::MidiMessage::createSysExMessage(
   140‚Üí                        data.data() + 1,  // Skip F0
   141‚Üí                        (int)data.size() - 2  // Exclude F0 and F7
   142‚Üí                    )
   143‚Üí                );
   144‚Üí            }
   145‚Üí        } else if (data.size() >= 1 && data.size() <= 3) {
   146‚Üí            // Valid short MIDI message (1-3 bytes)
   147‚Üí            output->sendMessageNow(
   148‚Üí                juce::MidiMessage(data.data(), (int)data.size())
   149‚Üí            );
   150‚Üí        } else {
   151‚Üí            std::cerr << "Warning: Invalid MIDI message length: " << data.size() << " bytes\n";
   152‚Üí        }
   153‚Üí    }
   154‚Üí
   155‚Üí    std::vector<std::vector<uint8_t>> getMessages() {
   156‚Üí        std::lock_guard<std::mutex> lock(queueMutex);
   157‚Üí        std::vector<std::vector<uint8_t>> result;
   158‚Üí        while (!messageQueue.empty()) {
   159‚Üí            result.push_back(messageQueue.front());
   160‚Üí            messageQueue.pop();
   161‚Üí        }
   162‚Üí        return result;
   163‚Üí    }
   164‚Üí
   165‚Üí    // MidiInputCallback interface
   166‚Üí    void handleIncomingMidiMessage(juce::MidiInput* source,
   167‚Üí                                  const juce::MidiMessage& message) override {
   168‚Üí        std::vector<uint8_t> data;
   169‚Üí
   170‚Üí        if (message.isSysEx()) {
   171‚Üí            auto sysexData = message.getSysExData();
   172‚Üí            auto size = message.getSysExDataSize();
   173‚Üí            // Add F0 header and F7 trailer
   174‚Üí            data.push_back(0xF0);
   175‚Üí            data.insert(data.end(), sysexData, sysexData + size);
   176‚Üí            data.push_back(0xF7);
   177‚Üí        } else {
   178‚Üí            auto rawData = message.getRawData();
   179‚Üí            auto size = message.getRawDataSize();
   180‚Üí            data.insert(data.end(), rawData, rawData + size);
   181‚Üí        }
   182‚Üí
   183‚Üí        std::lock_guard<std::mutex> lock(queueMutex);
   184‚Üí        messageQueue.push(data);
   185‚Üí    }
   186‚Üí
   187‚Üíprivate:
   188‚Üí    std::string portId;
   189‚Üí    std::string portName;
   190‚Üí    bool isInputPort;
   191‚Üí    std::unique_ptr<juce::MidiInput> input;
   192‚Üí    std::unique_ptr<juce::MidiOutput> output;
   193‚Üí    std::queue<std::vector<uint8_t>> messageQueue;
   194‚Üí    std::mutex queueMutex;
   195‚Üí};

```cpp
void handleIncomingMidiMessage(juce::MidiInput* source,
                              const juce::MidiMessage& message) override {
    std::vector<uint8_t> data;

    if (message.isSysEx()) {
        auto sysexData = message.getSysExData();

## Summary of Fixes

### 1. **JSON Builder Nested Array Bug** 
Fixed the comma placement logic in the `JsonBuilder` class:
- `startArray()` and `startObject()` now check `firstItem` and add commas for nested structures
- `key()` sets `firstItem = true` after outputting the colon (so values don't get extra commas)
- `value()` methods set `firstItem = false` (so next keys get commas)
- `endArray()` and `endObject()` set `firstItem = false` (so next items in parent get commas)

### 2. **SysEx Fragmentation Buffering**
Added proper buffering for fragmented SysEx messages:
- Detects when SysEx starts (F0) and begins buffering
- Accumulates fragments until F7 is received
- Only queues complete SysEx messages for the application
- Handles both fragmented and complete SysEx messages correctly

The backup command now runs successfully with no JSON parsing errors! The midi-snoop output still shows the fragmented SysEx at the CoreMIDI level (which is expected), but the JUCE server now properly reassembles them before delivering to your TypeScript application.

    58‚Üí  // Faders - FIXED: 0x28-0x2F (was 0x4D-0x54)
    59‚Üí  FADER1: 0x28, FADER2: 0x29, FADER3: 0x2A, FADER4: 0x2B,
    60‚Üí  FADER5: 0x2C, FADER6: 0x2D, FADER7: 0x2E, FADER8: 0x2F,
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí  // Track focus buttons - FIXED: 0x30-0x37 (was 0x29-0x30)
    63‚Üí  FOCUS1: 0x30, FOCUS2: 0x31, FOCUS3: 0x32, FOCUS4: 0x33,
    64‚Üí  FOCUS5: 0x34, FOCUS6: 0x35, FOCUS7: 0x36, FOCUS8: 0x37,
    65‚Üí
    66‚Üí  // Track control buttons - FIXED: 0x38-0x3F (was 0x39-0x40)
    67‚Üí  CONTROL1: 0x38, CONTROL2: 0x39, CONTROL3: 0x3A, CONTROL4: 0x3B,
    68‚Üí  CONTROL5: 0x3C, CONTROL6: 0x3D, CONTROL7: 0x3E, CONTROL8: 0x3F,
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí  // Side buttons - These will need further analysis in future phases
    71‚Üí  DEVICE: 0x69, MUTE: 0x6A, SOLO: 0x6B, RECORD: 0x6C,
    72‚Üí  UP: 0x68, DOWN: 0x6D, LEFT: 0x6E, RIGHT: 0x6F,
    73‚Üí} as const;
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí/**
    76‚Üí * LED color values for Launch Control XL 3
    77‚Üí */
    78‚Üíexport const LED_COLORS = {
    79‚Üí  OFF: 0x0C,
    80‚Üí  RED_LOW: 0x0D,
    81‚Üí  RED_FULL: 0x0F,
    82‚Üí  AMBER_LOW: 0x1D,
    83‚Üí  AMBER_FULL: 0x3F,
    84‚Üí  YELLOW: 0x3E,
    85‚Üí  GREEN_LOW: 0x1C,
    86‚Üí  GREEN_FULL: 0x3C,
    87‚Üí} as const;
    88‚Üí
    89‚Üí/**
    90‚Üí * Custom Mode Manager
    91‚Üí */
    92‚Üíexport class CustomModeManager extends EventEmitter {
    93‚Üí  private deviceManager: DeviceManager;
    94‚Üí  private options: Required<CustomModeManagerOptions>;
    95‚Üí  private modeCache: Map<number, { mode: CustomMode; timestamp: number }> = new Map();
    96‚Üí  private pendingOperations: Map<number, Promise<CustomMode>> = new Map();
    97‚Üí
    98‚Üí  constructor(options: CustomModeManagerOptions) {
    99‚Üí    super();
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí    this.deviceManager = options.deviceManager;
   102‚Üí    this.options = {
   103‚Üí      deviceManager: options.deviceManager,
   104‚Üí      autoSync: options.autoSync ?? true,
   105‚Üí      cacheTimeout: options.cacheTimeout ?? 300000, // 5 minutes
   106‚Üí    };
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí    this.setupEventHandlers();
   109‚Üí  }
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí  /**
   112‚Üí   * Setup event handlers
   113‚Üí   */
   114‚Üí  private setupEventHandlers(): void {
   115‚Üí    // Listen for device connection changes
   116‚Üí    this.deviceManager.on('device:connected', () => {
   117‚Üí      if (this.options.autoSync) {
   118‚Üí        this.syncAllModes().catch(error => {
   119‚Üí          this.emit('mode:error', error);
   120‚Üí        });
   121‚Üí      }
   122‚Üí    });
   123‚Üí
   124‚Üí    this.deviceManager.on('device:disconnected', () => {
   125‚Üí      this.clearCache();
   126‚Üí    });
   127‚Üí  }
   128‚Üí
   129‚Üí  /**
   130‚Üí   * Read a custom mode from the device
   131‚Üí   */
   132‚Üí  async readMode(slot: CustomModeSlot): Promise<CustomMode> {
   133‚Üí    this.validateSlot(slot);
   134‚Üí
   135‚Üí    // Check if we have a pending operation for this slot
   136‚Üí    const pending = this.pendingOperations.get(slot);
   137‚Üí    if (pending) {
   138‚Üí      return pending;
   139‚Üí    }
   140‚Üí
   141‚Üí    // Check cache
   142‚Üí    const cached = this.getCachedMode(slot);
   143‚Üí    if (cached) {
   144‚Üí      return cached;
   145‚Üí    }
   146‚Üí
   147‚Üí    // Create read operation
   148‚Üí    const operation = this.performReadMode(slot);
   149‚Üí    this.pendingOperations.set(slot, operation);
   150‚Üí
   151‚Üí    try {
   152‚Üí      const mode = await operation;
   153‚Üí      this.cacheMode(slot, mode);
   154‚Üí      this.emit('mode:loaded', slot, mode);
   155‚Üí      return mode;
   156‚Üí    } finally {
   157‚Üí      this.pendingOperations.delete(slot);
   158‚Üí    }
   159‚Üí  }
   160‚Üí
   161‚Üí  /**
   162‚Üí   * Perform actual mode read from device
   163‚Üí   */
   164‚Üí  private async performReadMode(slot: CustomModeSlot): Promise<CustomMode> {
   165‚Üí    const response = await this.deviceManager.readCustomMode(slot);
   166‚Üí    return this.parseCustomModeResponse(slot, response);
   167‚Üí  }
   168‚Üí
   169‚Üí  /**
   170‚Üí   * Write a custom mode to the device
   171‚Üí   */
   172‚Üí  async writeMode(slot: CustomModeSlot, mode: CustomMode): Promise<void> {
   173‚Üí    this.validateSlot(slot);
   174‚Üí    this.validateMode(mode);
   175‚Üí
   176‚Üí    // Convert to device format
   177‚Üí    const deviceMode = this.convertToDeviceFormat(slot, mode);
   178‚Üí
   179‚Üí    // Send to device
   180‚Üí    await this.deviceManager.writeCustomMode(slot, deviceMode);
   181‚Üí
   182‚Üí    // Update cache
   183‚Üí    this.cacheMode(slot, mode);
   184‚Üí    this.emit('mode:saved', slot, mode);
   185‚Üí  }
   186‚Üí
   187‚Üí  /**
   188‚Üí   * Parse custom mode response from device
   189‚Üí   */
   190‚Üí  private parseCustomModeResponse(slot: number, response: any): CustomMode {
   191‚Üí    // The response from DeviceManager is already partially parsed
   192‚Üí    // We need to enhance it with our type system
   193‚Üí
   194‚Üí    const mode: CustomMode = {
   195‚Üí      name: response.name || `Custom ${slot + 1}`,
   196‚Üí      controls: {},
   197‚Üí      leds: new Map(),
   198‚Üí      metadata: {
   199‚Üí        slot,
   200‚Üí        createdAt: new Date(),
   201‚Üí        modifiedAt: new Date(),
   202‚Üí      }
   203‚Üí    };
   204‚Üí
   205‚Üí    // Parse control mappings
   206‚Üí    if (response.controls) {
   207‚Üí      for (const control of response.controls) {
   208‚Üí        const controlId = this.getControlIdName(control.controlId);
   209‚Üí        if (controlId) {
   210‚Üí          mode.controls[controlId] = {
   211‚Üí            type: this.getControlType(control.controlId),
   212‚Üí            channel: control.channel,
   213‚Üí            cc: control.ccNumber,
   214‚Üí            min: control.minValue,
   215‚Üí            max: control.maxValue,
   216‚Üí            behaviour: control.behaviour as ControlBehaviour,
   217‚Üí          };
   218‚Üí        }
   219‚Üí      }
   220‚Üí    }
   221‚Üí
   222‚Üí    // Parse LED mappings
   223‚Üí    if (response.colors) {
   224‚Üí      for (const color of response.colors) {
   225‚Üí        const controlId = this.getControlIdName(color.controlId);
   226‚Üí        if (controlId && mode.leds) {
   227‚Üí          mode.leds.set(color.controlId, {
   228‚Üí            color: color.color,
   229‚Üí            behaviour: color.behaviour ?? 'static',
   230‚Üí          });
   231‚Üí        }
   232‚Üí      }
   233‚Üí    }
   234‚Üí
   235‚Üí    return mode;
   236‚Üí  }
   237‚Üí
   238‚Üí  /**
   239‚Üí   * Convert custom mode to device format
   240‚Üí   */
   241‚Üí  private convertToDeviceFormat(slot: number, mode: CustomMode): CustomMode {
   242‚Üí    const controls: ControlMapping[] = [];
   243‚Üí    const colors: ColorMapping[] = [];
   244‚Üí
   245‚Üí    // Convert control mappings
   246‚Üí    for (const [key, control] of Object.entries(mode.controls)) {
   247‚Üí      const controlId = this.getControlIdValue(key);
   248‚Üí      if (controlId !== undefined) {
   249‚Üí        const ctrl = control as any;
   250‚Üí        controls.push({
   251‚Üí          controlId,
   252‚Üí          channel: ctrl.channel,
   253‚Üí          ccNumber: ctrl.cc,
   254‚Üí          minValue: ctrl.min,
   255‚Üí          maxValue: ctrl.max,
   256‚Üí          behaviour: ctrl.behaviour,
   257‚Üí        });
   258‚Üí      }
   259‚Üí    }
   260‚Üí
   261‚Üí    // Convert LED mappings
   262‚Üí    for (const [key, led] of Object.entries(mode.leds || {})) {
   263‚Üí      const controlId = this.getControlIdValue(key);
   264‚Üí      if (controlId !== undefined) {
   265‚Üí        const ledConfig = led as any;
   266‚Üí        colors.push({
   267‚Üí          controlId,
   268‚Üí          color: ledConfig.color as number,
   269‚Üí          behaviour: ledConfig.behaviour,
   270‚Üí        });
   271‚Üí      }
   272‚Üí    }
   273‚Üí
   274‚Üí    return {
   275‚Üí      slot,
   276‚Üí      name: mode.name,
   277‚Üí      controls,
   278‚Üí      colors,
   279‚Üí    } as any;
   280‚Üí  }
   281‚Üí
   282‚Üí  /**
   283‚Üí   * Get control ID value from name
   284‚Üí   */
   285‚Üí  private getControlIdValue(name: string): number | undefined {
   286‚Üí    return (CONTROL_IDS as any)[name];
   287‚Üí  }
   288‚Üí
   289‚Üí  /**
   290‚Üí   * Get control ID name from value
   291‚Üí   */
   292‚Üí  private getControlIdName(value: number): string | undefined {
   293‚Üí    for (const [key, val] of Object.entries(CONTROL_IDS)) {
   294‚Üí      if (val === value) {
   295‚Üí        return key;
   296‚Üí      }
   297‚Üí    }
   298‚Üí    return undefined;
   299‚Üí  }
   300‚Üí
   301‚Üí  /**
   302‚Üí   * Get control type from control ID
   303‚Üí   * PHASE 1 FIX: Updated ranges to match corrected control ID mapping
   304‚Üí   */
   305‚Üí  private getControlType(controlId: number): ControlType {
   306‚Üí    // Encoders: 0x10-0x27 (top, middle, bottom rows)
   307‚Üí    if (controlId >= 0x10 && controlId <= 0x27) {
   308‚Üí      return 'knob';
   309‚Üí    }
   310‚Üí    // Faders: 0x28-0x2F
   311‚Üí    else if (controlId >= 0x28 && controlId <= 0x2F) {
   312‚Üí      return 'fader';
   313‚Üí    }
   314‚Üí    // Buttons: 0x30-0x3F and other button ranges
   315‚Üí    else {
   316‚Üí      return 'button';
   317‚Üí    }
   318‚Üí  }
   319‚Üí
   320‚Üí  /**
   321‚Üí   * Sync all modes from device
   322‚Üí   */
   323‚Üí  async syncAllModes(): Promise<CustomMode[]> {
   324‚Üí    const modes: CustomMode[] = [];
   325‚Üí
   326‚Üí    for (let slot = 0; slot < 16; slot++) {
   327‚Üí      try {
   328‚Üí        const mode = await this.readMode(slot as CustomModeSlot);
   329‚Üí        modes.push(mode);
   330‚Üí      } catch (error) {
   331‚Üí        // Log error but continue syncing other slots
   332‚Üí        console.error(`Failed to read mode from slot ${slot}:`, error);
   333‚Üí      }
   334‚Üí    }
   335‚Üí
   336‚Üí    return modes;
   337‚Üí  }
   338‚Üí
   339‚Üí  /**
   340‚Üí   * Copy a mode from one slot to another
   341‚Üí   */
   342‚Üí  async copyMode(sourceSlot: CustomModeSlot, targetSlot: CustomModeSlot): Promise<void> {
   343‚Üí    const sourceMode = await this.readMode(sourceSlot);
   344‚Üí
   345‚Üí    // Create a copy with new metadata
   346‚Üí    const targetMode: CustomMode = {
   347‚Üí      ...sourceMode,
   348‚Üí      metadata: {
   349‚Üí        ...sourceMode.metadata,
   350‚Üí        slot: targetSlot,
   351‚Üí        modifiedAt: new Date(),
   352‚Üí      }
   353‚Üí    };
   354‚Üí
   355‚Üí    await this.writeMode(targetSlot, targetMode);
   356‚Üí  }
   357‚Üí
   358‚Üí  /**
   359‚Üí   * Create a default mode
   360‚Üí   */
   361‚Üí  createDefaultMode(name?: string): CustomMode {
   362‚Üí    const mode: CustomMode = {
   363‚Üí      name: name || 'Default Mode',
   364‚Üí      controls: {},
   365‚Üí      leds: new Map(),
   366‚Üí      metadata: {
   367‚Üí        createdAt: new Date(),
   368‚Üí        modifiedAt: new Date(),
   369‚Üí      }
   370‚Üí    };
   371‚Üí
   372‚Üí    // Setup default control mappings
   373‚Üí    // Send A knobs - CC 13-20
   374‚Üí    for (let i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
   375‚Üí      const key = `SEND_A${i + 1}`;
   376‚Üí      mode.controls[key] = {
   377‚Üí        type: 'knob',
   378‚Üí        channel: 0,
   379‚Üí        cc: 13 + i,
   380‚Üí        min: 0,
   381‚Üí        max: 127,
   382‚Üí        behaviour: 'absolute',
   383‚Üí      };
   384‚Üí    }
   385‚Üí
   386‚Üí    // Send B knobs - CC 29-36
   387‚Üí    for (let i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
   388‚Üí      const key = `SEND_B${i + 1}`;
   389‚Üí      mode.controls[key] = {
   390‚Üí        type: 'knob',
   391‚Üí        channel: 0,
   392‚Üí        cc: 29 + i,
   393‚Üí        min: 0,
   394‚Üí        max: 127,
   395‚Üí        behaviour: 'absolute',
   396‚Üí      };
   397‚Üí    }
   398‚Üí
   399‚Üí    // Pan knobs - CC 49-56
   400‚Üí    for (let i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
   401‚Üí      const key = `PAN${i + 1}`;
   402‚Üí      mode.controls[key] = {
   403‚Üí        type: 'knob',
   404‚Üí        channel: 0,
   405‚Üí        cc: 49 + i,
   406‚Üí        min: 0,
   407‚Üí        max: 127,
   408‚Üí        behaviour: 'absolute',
   409‚Üí      };
   410‚Üí    }
   411‚Üí
   412‚Üí    // Faders - CC 77-84
   413‚Üí    for (let i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
   414‚Üí      const key = `FADER${i + 1}`;
   415‚Üí      mode.controls[key] = {
   416‚Üí        type: 'fader',
   417‚Üí        channel: 0,
   418‚Üí        cc: 77 + i,
   419‚Üí        min: 0,
   420‚Üí        max: 127,
   421‚Üí        behaviour: 'absolute',
   422‚Üí      };
   423‚Üí    }
   424‚Üí
   425‚Üí    // Setup default LED colors
   426‚Üí    for (let i = 0; i < 8; i++) {
   427‚Üí      mode.leds!.set(i + 0x10, { // Focus buttons start at 0x10
   428‚Üí        color: LED_COLORS.AMBER_LOW as any,
   429‚Üí        behaviour: 'static',
   430‚Üí      });
   431‚Üí
   432‚Üí      mode.leds!.set(i + 0x28, { // Control buttons start at 0x28
   433‚Üí        color: LED_COLORS.GREEN_LOW as any,
   434‚Üí        behaviour: 'static',
   435‚Üí      });
   436‚Üí    }
   437‚Üí
   438‚Üí    return mode;
   439‚Üí  }
   440‚Üí
   441‚Üí  /**
   442‚Üí   * Export mode to JSON
   443‚Üí   */
   444‚Üí  exportMode(mode: CustomMode): string {
   445‚Üí    return JSON.stringify(mode, null, 2);
   446‚Üí  }
   447‚Üí
   448‚Üí  /**
   449‚Üí   * Import mode from JSON
   450‚Üí   */
   451‚Üí  importMode(json: string): CustomMode {
   452‚Üí    const parsed = JSON.parse(json);
   453‚Üí    this.validateMode(parsed);
   454‚Üí    return parsed;
   455‚Üí  }
   456‚Üí
   457‚Üí  /**
   458‚Üí   * Validate slot number
   459‚Üí   */
   460‚Üí  private validateSlot(slot: number): void {
   461‚Üí    if (slot < 0 || slot > 15) {
   462‚Üí      throw new Error(`Invalid slot number: ${slot}. Must be 0-15.`);
   463‚Üí    }
   464‚Üí  }
   465‚Üí
   466‚Üí  /**
   467‚Üí   * Validate custom mode
   468‚Üí   */
   469‚Üí  private validateMode(mode: CustomMode): void {
   470‚Üí    if (!mode.name || typeof mode.name !== 'string') {
   471‚Üí      throw new Error('Mode must have a name');
   472‚Üí    }
   473‚Üí
   474‚Üí    if (!mode.controls || typeof mode.controls !== 'object') {
   475‚Üí      throw new Error('Mode must have controls object');
   476‚Üí    }
   477‚Üí
   478‚Üí    // Validate each control mapping
   479‚Üí    for (const [key, control] of Object.entries(mode.controls)) {
   480‚Üí      if (!this.getControlIdValue(key)) {
   481‚Üí        throw new Error(`Invalid control ID: ${key}`);
   482‚Üí      }
   483‚Üí
   484‚Üí      const ctrl = control as any; // Type assertion for validation
   485‚Üí
   486‚Üí      if (ctrl.channel < 0 || ctrl.channel > 15) {
   487‚Üí        throw new Error(`Invalid channel for ${key}: ${ctrl.channel}`);
   488‚Üí      }
   489‚Üí
   490‚Üí      if (ctrl.cc !== undefined && (ctrl.cc < 0 || ctrl.cc > 127)) {
   491‚Üí        throw new Error(`Invalid CC for ${key}: ${ctrl.cc}`);
   492‚Üí      }
   493‚Üí
   494‚Üí      if (ctrl.min !== undefined && (ctrl.min < 0 || ctrl.min > 127)) {
   495‚Üí        throw new Error(`Invalid min value for ${key}: ${ctrl.min}`);
   496‚Üí      }
   497‚Üí
   498‚Üí      if (ctrl.max !== undefined && (ctrl.max < 0 || ctrl.max > 127)) {
   499‚Üí        throw new Error(`Invalid max value for ${key}: ${ctrl.max}`);
   500‚Üí      }
   501‚Üí
   502‚Üí      if (ctrl.min !== undefined && ctrl.max !== undefined && ctrl.min > ctrl.max) {
   503‚Üí        throw new Error(`Min value greater than max for ${key}`);
   504‚Üí      }
   505‚Üí    }
   506‚Üí
   507‚Üí    // Validate LED mappings if present
   508‚Üí    if (mode.leds) {
   509‚Üí      for (const [key, led] of Object.entries(mode.leds)) {
   510‚Üí        if (!this.getControlIdValue(key)) {
   511‚Üí          throw new Error(`Invalid LED control ID: ${key}`);
   512‚Üí        }
   513‚Üí
   514‚Üí        const ledConfig = led as any; // Type assertion for validation
   515‚Üí        const validBehaviours = ['static', 'flash', 'pulse'];
   516‚Üí        if (ledConfig.behaviour && !validBehaviours.includes(ledConfig.behaviour)) {
   517‚Üí          throw new Error(`Invalid LED behaviour for ${key}: ${ledConfig.behaviour}`);
   518‚Üí        }
   519‚Üí      }
   520‚Üí    }
   521‚Üí  }
   522‚Üí
   523‚Üí  /**
   524‚Üí   * Get cached mode
   525‚Üí   */
   526‚Üí  private getCachedMode(slot: number): CustomMode | null {
   527‚Üí    const cached = this.modeCache.get(slot);
   528‚Üí
   529‚Üí    if (!cached) {
   530‚Üí      return null;
   531‚Üí    }
   532‚Üí
   533‚Üí    // Check if cache has expired
   534‚Üí    const now = Date.now();
   535‚Üí    if (now - cached.timestamp > this.options.cacheTimeout) {
   536‚Üí      this.modeCache.delete(slot);
   537‚Üí      return null;
   538‚Üí    }
   539‚Üí
   540‚Üí    return cached.mode;
   541‚Üí  }
   542‚Üí
   543‚Üí  /**
   544‚Üí   * Cache a mode
   545‚Üí   */
   546‚Üí  private cacheMode(slot: number, mode: CustomMode): void {
   547‚Üí    this.modeCache.set(slot, {
   548‚Üí      mode,
   549‚Üí      timestamp: Date.now(),
   550‚Üí    });
   551‚Üí
   552‚Üí    this.emit('cache:updated', slot);
   553‚Üí  }
   554‚Üí
   555‚Üí  /**
   556‚Üí   * Clear cache

    91‚Üí## Protocol Analysis
    92‚Üí
    93‚Üí### SysEx Format (TO Device)
    94‚Üí\```
    95‚ÜíF0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 45 [SLOT] [DATA...] F7
    96‚Üí\```
    97‚Üí- Bytes 0-7: Fixed header
    98‚Üí- Byte 8: **0x45** - Write command with data
    99‚Üí- Byte 9: Slot number (0x00 or 0x03)
   100‚Üí- Bytes 10+: Encoded custom mode data
   101‚Üí- Last byte: 0xF7 (SysEx end)
   102‚Üí
   103‚Üí### SysEx Format (FROM Device)
   104‚Üí\```
   105‚ÜíF0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 15 [SLOT] [STATUS] F7
   106‚Üí\```
   107‚Üí- Bytes 0-7: Fixed header
   108‚Üí- Byte 8: **0x15** - Write acknowledgment
   109‚Üí- Byte 9: Slot number
   110‚Üí- Byte 10: Status (0x06 or 0x07 = success)
   111‚Üí- Byte 11: 0xF7 (SysEx end)
   112‚Üí
   113‚Üí### Data Structure
   114‚Üí
   115‚ÜíThe 342-byte message contains:
   116‚Üí
   117‚Üí1. **Mode Name** (bytes 10-29):
   118‚Üí   - 0x01 0x20: Marker for name section
   119‚Üí   - 0x10 0x2A: Length or identifier
   120‚Üí   - ASCII text: "New Custom Mode"
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí2. **Control Definitions** (using 0x49 markers):
   123‚Üí   - Each control: `49 [ID] 02 [TYPE] 00 01 40 00 [CC] 7F 00`
   124‚Üí   - Control IDs: 0x10-0x3F (48 controls total)
   125‚Üí   - Types:
   126‚Üí     - 0x00: Encoder (rotary)
   127‚Üí     - 0x05: Encoder
   128‚Üí     - 0x09: Encoder
   129‚Üí     - 0x0D: Encoder
   130‚Üí     - 0x19: Button
   131‚Üí     - 0x25: Button
   132‚Üí
   133‚Üí3. **LED Colors** (using 0x60 markers):
   134‚Üí   - Format: `60 [ID]`
   135‚Üí   - One for each control
   136‚Üí
   137‚Üí## Key Findings
   138‚Üí
   139‚Üí1. **Command byte 0x45 is correct** for write operations
   140‚Üí2. **0x49 markers** are used for control definitions (not 0x48)
   141‚Üí3. **0x60 markers** are used for LED colors
   142‚Üí4. **DAW port activity** accompanies configuration changes
   143‚Üí5. **Two slots written**: The web editor writes the same mode to multiple slots
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí## Comparison with Our Library
   146‚Üí
   147‚ÜíOur library needs to:
   148‚Üí1. Use **0x49** markers instead of 0x48 for controls
   149‚Üí2. Use **0x60** markers for LED colors
   150‚Üí3. Use **0x40** in control definition bytes (not 0x48)
   151‚Üí4. Use **0x50** for button controls (slots 3)
   152‚Üí5. Include proper padding bytes (0x00)

```cpp
// Before - no buffering, fragments treated as separate messages
void handleIncomingMidiMessage(juce::MidiInput* source,
                              const juce::MidiMessage& message) override {
    std::vector<uint8_t> data;
    if (message.isSysEx()) {
        auto sysexData = message.getSysExData();
        auto size = message.getSysExDataSize();
        data.push_back(0xF0);
        data.insert(data.end(), sysexData, sysexData + size);
        data.push_back(0xF7);
    } else {
        auto rawData = message.getRawData();
        auto size = message.getRawDataSize();
        data.insert(data.end(), rawData, rawData + size);
    }
    std::lock_guard<std::mutex> lock(queueMutex);
    messageQueue.push(data);
}

// After - proper buffering of fragmented SysEx messages
void handleIncomingMidiMessage(juce::MidiInput* source,
                              const juce::MidiMessage& message) override {
    std::vector<uint8_t> data;
    auto rawData = message.getRawData();
    auto size = message.getRawDataSize();

    std::lock_guard<std::mutex> lock(queueMutex);

    // Check if this is a SysEx fragment
    bool startsWithF0 = (size > 0 && rawData[0] == 0xF0);
    bool endsWithF7 = (size > 0 && rawData[size - 1] == 0xF7);
    bool isSysExRelated = message.isSysEx() || startsWithF0 ||
                          (sysexBuffering && size > 0);

    if (isSysExRelated) {
        // Handle SysEx message or fragment
        if (startsWithF0) {
            // Start of new SysEx - initialize buffer
            sysexBuffer.clear();
            sysexBuffer.insert(sysexBuffer.end(), rawData, rawData + size);
            sysexBuffering = true;

            // Check if it's a complete SysEx in one message
            if (endsWithF7) {
                messageQueue.push(sysexBuffer);
                sysexBuffer.clear();
                sysexBuffering = false;
            }
        } else if (sysexBuffering) {
            // Continuation or end of SysEx
            sysexBuffer.insert(sysexBuffer.end(), rawData, rawData + size);

            if (endsWithF7) {
                // Complete SysEx received
                messageQueue.push(sysexBuffer);
                sysexBuffer.clear();
                sysexBuffering = false;
            }
        } else if (message.isSysEx()) {
            // JUCE already assembled complete SysEx
            auto sysexData = message.getSysExData();
            auto sysexSize = message.getSysExDataSize();
            data.push_back(0xF0);
            data.insert(data.end(), sysexData, sysexData + sysexSize);
            data.push_back(0xF7);
            messageQueue.push(data);
        }
    } else {
        // Regular MIDI message (non-SysEx)
        data.insert(data.end(), rawData, rawData + size);
        messageQueue.push(data);
    }
}

- **Error**: `SyntaxError: Expected ',' or ']' after array element in JSON at position 25`
- **Root Cause**: JsonBuilder class had incorrect comma placement logic for nested arrays. The `startArray()` method always reset `firstItem = true`, and `key()` set `firstItem = false`, causing missing commas between nested array elements.
- **Fix**: Updated all JsonBuilder methods to properly track and insert commas:
  - `startArray()` and `startObject()` now check `firstItem` and add commas for nested structures
  - `key()` sets `firstItem = true` (so values don't get extra commas)
  - `value()` methods set `firstItem = false` (so next keys get commas)
  - `endArray()` and `endObject()` set `firstItem = false` (so next items in parent get commas)
- **Verification**: After fix, backup command ran without JSON errors

### Error 2: SysEx Message Fragmentation
- **Error**: SysEx messages arriving in fragments causing parsing failures
- **Root Cause**: CoreMIDI delivers large SysEx messages in fragments (e.g., `F0 00 20` followed by `29 00 42...F7`), but JUCE server treated each fragment as a separate message
- **Fix**: Added buffering logic in `handleIncomingMidiMessage()`:
  - Detect SysEx start (F0) and initialize buffer
  - Accumulate fragments until F7 is received
  - Only queue complete messages
- **Verification**: Midi-snoop still shows fragments at CoreMIDI level (expected), but JUCE properly reassembles them

```typescript
private static parseName(data: number[]): string | undefined {
  let nameStart = -1;
  let nameLength = -1;

  // Look for name patterns - check multiple possible formats
  for (let i = 0; i < data.length - 4; i++) {
    // Format 2: 0x06 0x20 [length] [name bytes] - read response format
    if (data[i] === 0x06 && data[i + 1] === 0x20) {
      const lengthByte = data[i + 2];
      if (lengthByte === 0x1F) {
        return undefined; // Factory data
      }
      // Use the length byte to know exactly how many characters to read
      nameLength = lengthByte ?? 0;
      nameStart = i + 3;
      break;
    }
    // ... other formats ...
  }

  if (nameStart >= 0) {
    const nameBytes = [];
    // If we have an explicit length from the header, use it
    if (nameLength > 0) {
      for (let i = 0; i < nameLength && nameStart + i < data.length; i++) {
        const byte = data[nameStart + i];
        if (byte !== undefined && byte >= 0x20 && byte <= 0x7E) {
          nameBytes.push(byte);
        }
      }
    }
    // ... fallback logic ...
    if (nameBytes.length > 0) {
      return String.fromCharCode(...nameBytes).trim();
    }
  }
  return undefined;
}
```

**Key Change**: Now uses the length byte from the header (`06 20 [length]`) to read exactly the right number of characters, avoiding premature termination when encountering bytes that look like markers.

}

import { LaunchControlXL3 } from '../src';

async function dumpLabelBytes() {

  const device = new LaunchControlXL3({ midiBackend: backend });

  try {
    await device.connect();
    console.log('Connected to device');

    console.log('\n=== MODE DATA ANALYSIS ===\n');

    // Access the raw SysEx response data
    // @ts-ignore - accessing private method for debugging
    const rawResponses = device.customModeManager?.lastRawResponses;

    if (rawResponses && rawResponses.length > 0) {
      const firstPage = rawResponses[0];
      console.log(`First page length: ${firstPage.length} bytes`);
      console.log('\nBytes around position 253 (label section):');

      for (let i = 250; i < Math.min(420, firstPage.length); i++) {
        const byte = firstPage[i];
        const hex = `0x${byte.toString(16).padStart(2, '0')}`;
        const ascii = byte >= 0x20 && byte <= 0x7E ? `'${String.fromCharCode(byte)}'` : '   ';
        const isMarker = byte >= 0x60 && byte <= 0x6F ? ' [MARKER]' : '';
        const isControlId = byte >= 0x10 && byte <= 0x3F ? ' [CTRL_ID]' : '';
        const isTerminator = byte === 0x60 ? ' [TERM]' : '';

        console.log(`${i}: ${hex} ${ascii}${isMarker}${isControlId}${isTerminator}`);
      }
    }

    await device.disconnect();
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error:', error);
  }
}

```typescript
private static parseName(data: number[]): string | undefined {
  let nameStart = -1;
  let nameLength = -1;

  // Look for name patterns
  for (let i = 0; i < data.length - 4; i++) {
    // Format 2: 0x06 0x20 [length] [name bytes] - read response format
    if (data[i] === 0x06 && data[i + 1] === 0x20) {
      const lengthByte = data[i + 2];
      if (lengthByte === 0x1F) {
        return undefined; // Factory data
      }
      // Use the length byte to know exactly how many characters to read
      nameLength = lengthByte ?? 0;
      nameStart = i + 3;
      break;
    }
  }

  if (nameStart >= 0 && nameLength > 0) {
    const nameBytes = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < nameLength && nameStart + i < data.length; i++) {
      const byte = data[nameStart + i];
      if (byte !== undefined && byte >= 0x20 && byte <= 0x7E) {
        nameBytes.push(byte);
      }
    }
    if (nameBytes.length > 0) {
      return String.fromCharCode(...nameBytes).trim();
    }
  }
  return undefined;
}
```

**Key Change**: Now uses the length byte from the header to read exactly the right number of characters, preventing premature termination.

```typescript
private static parseName(data: number[]): string | undefined {
  let nameStart = -1;
  let nameLength = -1;

  // Look for name patterns
  for (let i = 0; i < data.length - 4; i++) {
    // Format 2: 0x06 0x20 [length] [name bytes] - read response format
    if (data[i] === 0x06 && data[i + 1] === 0x20) {
      const lengthByte = data[i + 2];
      if (lengthByte === 0x1F) {
        return undefined; // Factory data
      }
      // Use the length byte to know exactly how many characters to read
      nameLength = lengthByte ?? 0;
      nameStart = i + 3;
      break;
    }
  }

  if (nameStart >= 0 && nameLength > 0) {
    const nameBytes = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < nameLength && nameStart + i < data.length; i++) {
      const byte = data[nameStart + i];
      if (byte !== undefined && byte >= 0x20 && byte <= 0x7E) {
        nameBytes.push(byte);
      }
    }
    if (nameBytes.length > 0) {
      return String.fromCharCode(...nameBytes).trim();
    }
  }
  return undefined;
}
```

**Result**: Mode name "CHANNEVE" now parses correctly instead of being truncated to "C".

### Breakthrough Discovery:
**Control Label Protocol Format**: `[0x60 + length] [controlID] [name_bytes] [0x60_terminator]`

The marker byte encodes the string length:
- Marker range 0x60-0x6F allows for strings 0-15 characters long
- To parse: `length = marker_byte - 0x60`
- Read exactly `length` bytes as the name
- Expect 0x60 terminator after name bytes

## Summary

Successfully fixed the Launch Control XL3 library's mode name and control name parsing! 

### Results

**Before:** 14% accuracy (3/21 controls)
**After:** 95% accuracy (20/21 controls)

The only "failure" is Control 16, which shows "TEST1" instead of "High Pass" because we intentionally changed it during empirical testing.

### Key Discoveries

Through systematic testing with the Novation Components web editor and MIDI traffic analysis, I discovered the protocol format:

1. **Mode Name Format:**
   ```
   06 20 [length] [name_bytes]
   ```
   The length byte indicates exactly how many characters to read.

2. **Control Label Format:**
   ```
   [0x60 + length] [controlID] [name_bytes] [0x60_terminator]
   ```
   The marker byte encodes the string length (0x60-0x6F = 0-15 characters).

3. **Control ID Mapping:**
   Label IDs 25-28 (0x19-0x1c) map to control IDs 26-29 with a +1 offset.

### Changes Made

**File:** `SysExParser.ts:620-741`

- Rewrote `parseControlLabels()` to use length-encoding scheme
- Updated `mapLabelControlId()` to handle the +1 offset for IDs 25-28
- Simplified parsing logic from 180+ lines of complex heuristics to ~90 lines of straightforward length-based reading

The library now correctly fetches all mode names and control names from the device!

async function checkLedData() {

```md
# Launch Control XL3 Protocol Specification

**Version:** 1.0
**Last Updated:** 2025-09-30
**Status:** Verified with hardware

## Overview

The Launch Control XL3 communicates via MIDI SysEx messages. Custom modes are fetched and stored using a multi-page protocol.

## Table of Contents

- [Quick Reference](#quick-reference)
- [Custom Mode Fetch Protocol](#custom-mode-fetch-protocol)
- [Data Structures](#data-structures)
- [Examples](#examples)
- [Discovery Methodology](#discovery-methodology)

---

## Quick Reference

**Canonical Protocol Specification:** See [`../formats/launch_control_xl3.ksy`](../formats/launch_control_xl3.ksy)

The `.ksy` file is a Kaitai Struct specification that defines the **exact byte layout** of all protocol structures. It is:
- Machine-readable (can generate parsers)
- Human-readable (declarative format)
- Unambiguous (specifies exact byte positions, types, and sizes)
- Version-controlled (tracks protocol changes)

**Why .ksy?** It eliminates ambiguity. Instead of prose like "a length byte followed by name bytes", the spec states:
\```yaml
- id: name_length
  type: u1
- id: name_bytes
  size: name_length
  type: str
  encoding: ASCII
\```

---

## Custom Mode Fetch Protocol

### High-Level Flow

1. **Device Handshake** (4-message sequence)
   - Client sends SYN
   - Device responds with SYN-ACK containing serial number
   - Client sends Universal Device Inquiry (ACK)
   - Device responds with device info

2. **Slot Selection** (via DAW port)
   - Send Note On Ch16
   - Send CC query on Ch8
   - Device responds with current slot
   - Send CC selection on Ch7
   - Send Note Off Ch16

3. **Mode Fetch** (3 SysEx pages)
   - Request page 0 (controls 0-15 + mode name + labels)
   - Request page 1 (controls 16-31 + labels)
   - Request page 2 (controls 32-47 + labels)

### Multi-Page Structure

Custom mode data is split across **3 SysEx response pages** due to MIDI message size limits:

| Page | Controls | Contains Mode Name? | Label Control IDs |
|------|----------|---------------------|-------------------|
| 0    | 0-15     | Yes (first page only) | 0x10-0x1F |
| 1    | 16-31    | No | 0x20-0x2F |
| 2    | 32-47    | No | 0x30-0x3F |

Each page follows the same structure defined in `launch_control_xl3.ksy`.

---

## Data Structures

### Page Structure

\```
[Page Header]
[Mode Name Section]  ‚Üê Only in page 0
[16√ó Control Definitions]
[Label Section]
\```

**See [`launch_control_xl3.ksy`](../formats/launch_control_xl3.ksy) types:**
- `custom_mode_page` - Complete page structure
- `page_header` - Fixed 5-byte header
- `mode_name` - Variable-length name (page 0 only)
- `control_definition` - 7-byte control spec
- `label_section` - Variable-length labels

### Control Definition (7 bytes)

Each control is defined by exactly 7 bytes:

\```
Offset | Type | Field        | Values
-------|------|--------------|------------------
0      | u1   | control_type | 0x00, 0x05, 0x09, 0x0D, 0x19, 0x25
1      | u1   | control_id   | 0x10-0x3F (16-63)
2      | u1   | midi_channel | 0-15
3      | u1   | cc_number    | 0-127
4      | u1   | min_value    | Usually 0
5      | u1   | max_value    | Usually 127
6      | u1   | behavior     | 0x0C=absolute, 0x0D=relative, 0x0E=toggle
\```

### Mode Name Encoding

**Format:** `06 20 [length] [name_bytes...]`

- `06 20` - Fixed marker
- `length` - Number of characters (0-8)
- `name_bytes` - ASCII characters

**Example:**
\```
06 20 08 43 48 41 4E 4E 45 56 45
      ‚Üë  C  H  A  N  N  E  V  E
      ‚îî‚îÄ length = 8 chars
\```

### Control Label Encoding ‚≠ê

**Critical Discovery:** Labels use **length-encoding** where the marker byte encodes the string length.

**Format:** `[0x60 + length] [control_id] [name_bytes...] [next_marker]`

The marker byte range `0x60-0x6F` allows strings of 0-15 characters:
- `0x60` = empty string (0 chars)
- `0x65` = 5-character string
- `0x69` = 9-character string
- `0x6F` = 15-character string (maximum)

**Length calculation:**
\```
length = marker_byte - 0x60
\```

**Control ID Mapping:**
- Most label control IDs map directly to control IDs
- **Exception:** Label IDs 0x19-0x1C (25-28) map to control IDs 26-29 (+1 offset)

---

## Examples

### Example 1: "TEST1" Label

\```
65 10 54 45 53 54 31 60
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  T  E  S  T  1
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Control ID 0x10
‚îî‚îÄ Marker 0x65 = 0x60 + 5 ‚Üí 5 characters
\```

### Example 2: "High Pass" Label

\```
69 14 48 69 67 68 20 50 61 73 73 60
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  H  i  g  h     P  a  s  s
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Control ID 0x14 (20)
‚îî‚îÄ Marker 0x69 = 0x60 + 9 ‚Üí 9 characters
\```

### Example 3: Empty Label

\```
60 11 60
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Next marker or terminator
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Control ID 0x11
‚îî‚îÄ Marker 0x60 = 0x60 + 0 ‚Üí 0 characters (empty)
\```

### Example 4: Control ID Mapping Exception

Label with control ID 0x19 (25) maps to actual control ID 26:

\```
68 19 4C 6F 77 20 46 72 65 71
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  L  o  w     F  r  e  q
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Label ID 0x19 ‚Üí maps to control 26
‚îî‚îÄ Marker 0x68 = 8 chars
\```

**Mapping rule:**
\```typescript
function mapLabelControlId(labelId: number): number {
  if (labelId >= 25 && labelId <= 28) {
    return labelId + 1;  // Labels 25-28 ‚Üí controls 26-29
  }
  return labelId;  // Direct mapping for all others
}
\```

---

## Discovery Methodology

**How was this protocol reverse-engineered?**

### Phase 1: Initial Analysis
1. Used existing heuristic parser (180+ lines, ~14% accuracy)
2. Captured MIDI traffic with CoreMIDI spy during device operations
3. Compared parser output with expected control names

### Phase 2: Systematic Testing
1. **Tools Used:**
   - Novation Components web editor (ground truth)
   - Playwright browser automation (programmatic control)
   - CoreMIDI MIDI snooping tool (traffic capture)
   - Custom analysis scripts

2. **Methodology:**
   - Changed control name from "High Pass" to "TEST1" in web editor
   - Sent modified mode to device via web editor
   - Captured exact MIDI bytes sent during operation
   - Retrieved mode from device
   - Compared byte sequences

3. **Key Discovery:**
   \```
   "TEST1" (5 chars):     65 10 54 45 53 54 31 60
   "High Pass" (9 chars): 69 14 48 69 67 68 20 50 61 73 73 60
   \```

   Realized: `0x65 = 0x60 + 5` and `0x69 = 0x60 + 9`

   **The marker byte encodes the string length!**

### Phase 3: Validation
1. Implemented length-encoding parser
2. Tested against all 21 named controls
3. Achieved 95% accuracy (20/21 correct)
4. One "failure" was intentional test data ("TEST1")

### Phase 4: Documentation
1. Created Kaitai Struct specification (`.ksy` file)
2. Validated spec by generating parser and comparing output
3. Documented control ID mapping exception (25-28 ‚Üí 26-29)

---

## LED Control

**Important:** LED states are **NOT** stored in custom mode configurations.

LEDs are controlled via separate real-time MIDI messages:
- Message type: `0x78` (LED_CONTROL)
- Format: Standard MIDI CC or custom SysEx

Custom modes only store:
- Control definitions (CC mappings, channels, behaviors)
- Control labels (names)
- Mode name

---

## Parser Implementation

**Current Implementation:** `src/core/SysExParser.ts`

The parser follows the protocol specification exactly:

1. **Mode Name Parsing:**
   \```typescript
   // Format: 06 20 [length] [name_bytes]
   const lengthByte = data[i + 2];
   const nameLength = lengthByte;
   const nameBytes = data.slice(i + 3, i + 3 + nameLength);
   \```

2. **Control Label Parsing:**
   \```typescript
   // Format: [0x60 + length] [controlID] [name_bytes]
   const length = markerByte - 0x60;
   const controlId = data[i + 1];
   const nameBytes = data.slice(i + 2, i + 2 + length);
   const canonicalId = mapLabelControlId(controlId);
   \```

**Lines of code:** ~90 (down from 180+ heuristic version)
**Accuracy:** 95%+ (100% when test data removed)

---

- **Formal Specification:** [`../formats/launch_control_xl3.ksy`](../formats/launch_control_xl3.ksy)
- **Parser Implementation:** [`../src/core/SysExParser.ts`](../src/core/SysExParser.ts)

1. **The `.ksy` file is the source of truth** for byte-level protocol details
2. **Test changes empirically** using the web editor + MIDI spy methodology
3. **Control ID mapping exception** (25-28 ‚Üí 26-29) is hardware-specific, not a bug

5. **No LED data in custom modes** - don't waste time looking for it

## Key Components

### 1. LaunchControlXL3 (src/LaunchControlXL3.ts)

**Purpose:** Main user-facing API

**Responsibilities:**
- Device connection/disconnection
- High-level control operations
- Event management
- Delegates to specialized managers

**Key Methods:**
- `connect()` - Initialize device connection
- `readCustomMode(slot)` - Fetch mode from device
- `writeCustomMode(slot, mode)` - Send mode to device
- `setControlValue(id, value)` - Real-time control

### 2. DeviceManager (src/device/DeviceManager.ts)

**Purpose:** Low-level device communication

**Responsibilities:**
- MIDI port management
- 4-message handshake protocol
- DAW port control
- Message send/receive

**Handshake Sequence:**
\```typescript
1. Send Novation SYN (F0 00 20 29 00 42 02 F7)
2. Receive SYN-ACK with serial number
3. Send Universal Device Inquiry (F0 7E 7F 06 01 F7)
4. Receive device info (manufacturer, model, firmware)
\```

### 3. CustomModeManager (src/modes/CustomModeManager.ts)

**Purpose:** Custom mode operations

**Responsibilities:**
- Slot selection via DAW port
- Multi-page mode fetch
- Mode writing
- Data validation

**Fetch Process:**
\```typescript
1. Select slot (via DAW port, 6-step protocol)
2. Request page 0 ‚Üí Parse controls 0-15 + mode name + labels
3. Request page 1 ‚Üí Parse controls 16-31 + labels
4. Request page 2 ‚Üí Parse controls 32-47 + labels
5. Merge all data into CustomMode object
\```

### 4. SysExParser (src/core/SysExParser.ts)

**Purpose:** Protocol parsing and message building

**Responsibilities:**
- Parse mode name (length-encoded)
- Parse control definitions (7 bytes each)
- Parse control labels (length-encoded)
- Build SysEx messages for device
- Control ID mapping (25-28 ‚Üí 26-29 exception)

**Critical Functions:**
- `parseName()` - Parse mode name with length byte
- `parseControlLabels()` - Length-encoding label parser
- `mapLabelControlId()` - Handle control ID mapping exception

**Parsing Strategy:**
\```typescript
// Mode name: 06 20 [length] [name_bytes]
const length = data[i + 2];
const name = String.fromCharCode(...data.slice(i + 3, i + 3 + length));

// Labels: [0x60 + length] [control_id] [name_bytes]
const length = markerByte - 0x60;
const controlId = data[i + 1];
const name = String.fromCharCode(...data.slice(i + 2, i + 2 + length));
const canonicalId = mapLabelControlId(controlId);
\```

### 5. MIDI Backends (src/backends/)

**Purpose:** Abstract MIDI communication

**Implementations:**
- **JuceMidiBackend** - HTTP server (JUCE C++ backend)
- **WebMidiBackend** - Browser Web MIDI API

**Interface:**
\```typescript
interface MidiBackend {
  connect(): Promise<void>;
  disconnect(): Promise<void>;
  sendSysEx(data: number[]): Promise<void>;
  onMessage(callback: (data: number[]) => void): void;
}
\```

## Data Flow

### Reading a Custom Mode

\```
User Code
  ‚îÇ
  ‚îú‚îÄ> device.readCustomMode(0)
  ‚îÇ
DeviceManager
  ‚îÇ
  ‚îú‚îÄ> Select slot via DAW port (6-step protocol)
  ‚îÇ
CustomModeManager
  ‚îÇ
  ‚îú‚îÄ> Request page 0
  ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ> Parse with SysExParser
  ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ> parseName() ‚Üí "CHANNEVE"
  ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ> parseControls() ‚Üí 16 controls
  ‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ> parseControlLabels() ‚Üí ["High Pass", "Low Pass", ...]
  ‚îÇ
  ‚îú‚îÄ> Request page 1
  ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ> Parse 16 more controls + labels
  ‚îÇ
  ‚îú‚îÄ> Request page 2
  ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ> Parse final 16 controls + labels
  ‚îÇ
  ‚îî‚îÄ> Merge into CustomMode {
        name: "CHANNEVE",
        controls: { ... 48 controls ... }
      }
\```

### Label Parsing Detail

\```
Input: 69 14 48 69 67 68 20 50 61 73 73 60
       ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  H  i  g  h     P  a  s  s
       ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Control ID 0x14 (20)
       ‚îî‚îÄ Marker 0x69

Step 1: Calculate length
  length = 0x69 - 0x60 = 9

Step 2: Read control ID
  controlId = 0x14

Step 3: Read name bytes
  nameBytes = [0x48, 0x69, 0x67, 0x68, 0x20, 0x50, 0x61, 0x73, 0x73]
  name = "High Pass"

Step 4: Map control ID
  canonicalId = mapLabelControlId(0x14) = 0x14  // Direct mapping

Step 5: Store
  controlNames.set(0x14, "High Pass")
\```

interface CustomMode {
  name: string;                              // Max 8 chars
  controls: Record<string, ControlMapping>;  // 48 controls

}

  controlId: number;         // 0x10-0x3F
  ccNumber: number;          // 0-127
  channel: number;           // 0-15 (MIDI channels)
  minValue: number;          // Usually 0
  maxValue: number;          // Usually 127
  behavior: 'absolute' | 'relative' | 'toggle';

}

## Common Pitfalls

### 1. ‚ùå Control ID Confusion

**Problem:** Label control IDs 25-28 don't match control IDs 26-29

**Solution:** Always use `mapLabelControlId(labelId)` when parsing labels

\```typescript
// WRONG
controlNames.set(labelControlId, name);

// CORRECT
const canonicalId = mapLabelControlId(labelControlId);
controlNames.set(canonicalId, name);
\```

### 2. ‚ùå ASCII Overlap Ambiguity

**Problem:** Bytes 0x60-0x6F are both marker bytes AND valid ASCII letters

**Solution:** Use length-encoding, don't try to detect patterns

\```typescript
// WRONG - trying to detect "looks like a marker"
if (byte >= 0x60 && byte <= 0x6F && nextByte >= 0x10) {
  // Might be a marker... or might be a letter 'h' in "High Pass"
}

// CORRECT - calculate length, read exact bytes
const length = markerByte - 0x60;
const nameBytes = data.slice(offset, offset + length);
\```

### 3. ‚ùå Assuming LED Data Exists

**Problem:** Looking for LED configurations in custom mode fetch

**Solution:** LED states are NOT in custom mode data. They're real-time only.

\```typescript
// WRONG
const ledColor = parseLedData(data);

// CORRECT
// Custom modes don't contain LED data.
// Use LED_CONTROL messages (0x78) for real-time LED control.
\```

### 4. ‚ùå Forgetting Multi-Page Structure

**Problem:** Trying to parse all 48 controls from one page

**Solution:** Always fetch and merge all 3 pages

\```typescript
// WRONG
const mode = parseCustomMode(page0Data);  // Only has 16 controls!

// CORRECT
const page0 = parseCustomModePage(page0Data);  // Controls 0-15
const page1 = parseCustomModePage(page1Data);  // Controls 16-31
const page2 = parseCustomModePage(page2Data);  // Controls 32-47
const mode = mergePages(page0, page1, page2);  // All 48 controls
\```

## Development Workflow

### Making Protocol Changes

1. **Update formal spec:** Edit `formats/launch_control_xl3.ksy`
2. **Validate spec:** Run `kaitai-struct-compiler --help formats/launch_control_xl3.ksy`
3. **Update parser:** Modify `src/core/SysExParser.ts` to match
4. **Update docs:** Sync changes to `docs/PROTOCOL.md`
5. **Test empirically:** Use backup utility + real device
6. **Add test case:** Save device capture in `backup/` directory

### Debugging Protocol Issues

1. **Capture MIDI traffic:**
   \```bash
   cd ../../modules/coremidi/midi-snoop
   make run
   # Traffic appears in spy output
   \```

2. **Enable debug logging:** Parser already has extensive console.log statements

3. **Compare with web editor:**
   - Use Novation Components web editor as ground truth
   - Use Playwright automation to control web editor programmatically
   - Compare byte sequences

4. **Analyze with .ksy viewer:**
   - Use Kaitai Struct IDE: https://ide.kaitai.io/
   - Upload `.ksy` file and binary data
   - Visualize parsed structures

## Performance Characteristics

- **Handshake:** ~500ms (4 message round-trips)
- **Slot selection:** ~300ms (6-step DAW port protocol)
- **Page fetch:** ~100ms per page
- **Total mode fetch:** ~1.5-2.0 seconds
- **Parsing:** <10ms (in-memory, no I/O)

## Key Decisions & Rationale

### Why Not Use Generated Kaitai Parser?

**Decision:** Keep hand-written parser in `SysExParser.ts`

**Rationale:**
1. Parser is now simple (90 lines) after removing heuristics
2. Generated parser is less readable (~200 lines)
3. No build step complexity
4. Direct control over error messages
5. TypeScript-native (no JS/TS interop)

**Keep `.ksy` file because:**
- Serves as formal, unambiguous spec
- Can generate visualizations
- Can validate changes before coding
- Machine-readable documentation

### Why Length-Encoding?

**Discovery:** Through empirical testing, not speculation

**Evidence:**
\```
"TEST1": 65 10 54 45 53 54 31 60
         ‚Üë
         0x65 = 0x60 + 5 characters

"High Pass": 69 14 48 69 67 68 20 50 61 73 73 60
             ‚Üë
             0x69 = 0x60 + 9 characters
\```

**Impact:** Eliminates all parsing ambiguity. No heuristics needed.

### Why Multi-Page Protocol?

**Constraint:** MIDI SysEx message size limits

**Solution:** Device splits 48 controls across 3 pages of 16 controls each

**Trade-off:** More round-trips (slower), but reliable pagination

## Complete Bidirectional MIDI Conversation

This document contains the complete MIDI conversation captured between the Novation web editor and the Launch Control XL3 device when sending a custom mode.

When the web editor sends a custom mode to the device:

# Launch Control XL3 DAW Port Protocol Documentation

## Overview

The Launch Control XL3 uses a dual-port MIDI system for communication:
- **MIDI Port**: Standard port for SysEx data transfers (read/write custom modes, device info)
- **DAW Port**: Out-of-band control port for slot selection, mode changes, and other control messages

## Critical Discovery: Slot Selection via DAW Port

The slot byte in SysEx messages (position 9) **does not control where data is written**. Instead, the device uses an out-of-band slot selection mechanism via the DAW port.

### The Problem
When writing custom mode data using only the MIDI port:
- Sending to slot 0 (0x00) would write to physical slot 2
- The slot byte in the SysEx message was being ignored
- The device was using a previously selected slot or defaulting to slot 2

### The Solution
The Novation Components web editor uses the DAW port to select slots before writing:

   107‚Üí### Implementation Example (Updated)
   108‚Üí
   109‚Üí\```typescript
   110‚Üí// DawPortController with two-phase protocol
   111‚Üíclass DawPortControllerImpl {
   112‚Üí  async selectSlot(slot: number): Promise<void> {
   113‚Üí    const physicalSlot = slot + 1;
   114‚Üí    const ccValue = physicalSlot + 5;
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí    // Phase 1: Query current slot
   117‚Üí    await this.sendMessage([0x9F, 11, 127]);  // Note On ch16
   118‚Üí    await this.sendMessage([0xB7, 30, 0]);    // CC ch8, query
   119‚Üí    // Wait for device response (CC ch7)...
   120‚Üí    await this.sendMessage([0x9F, 11, 0]);    // Note Off ch16
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí    // Small delay between phases
   123‚Üí    await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 10));
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí    // Phase 2: Set target slot
   126‚Üí    await this.sendMessage([0x9F, 11, 127]);  // Note On ch16
   127‚Üí    await this.sendMessage([0xB6, 30, ccValue]); // CC ch7, set slot
   128‚Üí    await this.sendMessage([0x9F, 11, 0]);    // Note Off ch16
   129‚Üí
   130‚Üí    // Give device time to process
   131‚Üí    await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 50));
   132‚Üí  }
   133‚Üí}
   134‚Üí\```

   137‚Üí
   138‚Üí### Writing to a Specific Slot
   139‚Üí1. Send two-phase slot selection protocol to DAW port
   140‚Üí2. Wait for device to process (~50ms)
   141‚Üí3. Send SysEx write command to MIDI port
   142‚Üí   - Use slot byte 0x00
   143‚Üí   - Use flag byte to indicate actual slot (0x00 for slot 1, 0x01 for slot 2, etc.)
   144‚Üí4. Device writes to the selected slot
   145‚Üí
   146‚Üí### Reading from a Specific Slot
   147‚Üí1. Send two-phase slot selection protocol to DAW port
   148‚Üí2. Send SysEx read command to MIDI port
   149‚Üí3. Device returns data from the selected slot
   150‚Üí

   246‚Üí## DAW Port Protocol
   247‚Üí
   248‚Üí### Overview
   249‚Üí
   250‚ÜíThe Launch Control XL3 uses a **dual-port MIDI system**:
   251‚Üí- **MIDI Port**: SysEx data transfers (read/write custom modes, device info)
   252‚Üí- **DAW Port**: Out-of-band control (slot selection, mode switching)
   253‚Üí
   254‚Üí**Critical Discovery:** The slot byte in SysEx messages does NOT control target slot. Instead, the device uses an out-of-band slot selection protocol via the DAW port.
   255‚Üí
   256‚Üí### Two-Phase Slot Selection Protocol
   257‚Üí
   258‚ÜíSlot selection requires a bidirectional negotiation with the device:
   259‚Üí
   260‚Üí#### Phase 1: Query Current Slot (6 messages)
   261‚Üí\```
   262‚Üí1. Client ‚Üí Device: Note On  (Ch16, Note 11, Vel 127)  [0x9F, 0x0B, 0x7F]
   263‚Üí2. Client ‚Üí Device: CC Query (Ch8,  CC 30,  Val 0)     [0xB7, 0x1E, 0x00]
   264‚Üí3. Device ‚Üí Client: Note On echo
   265‚Üí4. Device ‚Üí Client: CC Response (Ch7, CC 30, current_slot)
   266‚Üí5. Client ‚Üí Device: Note Off (Ch16, Note 11, Vel 0)    [0x8F, 0x0B, 0x00]
   267‚Üí6. Device ‚Üí Client: Note Off echo
   268‚Üí\```
   269‚Üí
   270‚Üí#### Phase 2: Set Target Slot (3 messages)
   271‚Üí\```
   272‚Üí1. Client ‚Üí Device: Note On  (Ch16, Note 11, Vel 127)  [0x9F, 0x0B, 0x7F]
   273‚Üí2. Client ‚Üí Device: CC Set   (Ch7,  CC 30,  target_slot) [0xB6, 0x1E, value]
   274‚Üí3. Client ‚Üí Device: Note Off (Ch16, Note 11, Vel 0)    [0x8F, 0x0B, 0x00]
   275‚Üí\```
   276‚Üí
   277‚Üí### Channel Mapping
   278‚Üí
   279‚Üí- **Channel 16 (0x0F)**: Note On/Off wrapper messages
   280‚Üí- **Channel 8 (0x07)**: Query messages (CC value = 0)
   281‚Üí- **Channel 7 (0x06)**: Set commands and device responses
   282‚Üí
   283‚Üí### Slot Value Encoding
   284‚Üí
   285‚ÜíCC values map to physical slots with an offset:
   286‚Üí
   287‚Üí| Physical Slot | API Slot | CC Value |
   288‚Üí|---------------|----------|----------|
   289‚Üí| 1 | 0 | 6 |
   290‚Üí| 2 | 1 | 7 |
   291‚Üí| 3 | 2 | 8 |
   292‚Üí| ... | ... | ... |
   293‚Üí| 15 | 14 | 20 |
   294‚Üí
   295‚Üí**Formula:**
   296‚Üí\```
   297‚ÜíCC_Value = Physical_Slot + 5
   298‚ÜíCC_Value = API_Slot + 6
   299‚Üí\```
   300‚Üí
   301‚Üí### Implementation Example
   302‚Üí
   303‚Üí\```typescript
   304‚Üíasync selectSlot(apiSlot: number): Promise<void> {
   305‚Üí  const ccValue = apiSlot + 6;  // Convert API slot to CC value
   306‚Üí
   307‚Üí  // Phase 1: Query current slot
   308‚Üí  await sendDAW([0x9F, 0x0B, 0x7F]);  // Note On Ch16
   309‚Üí  await sendDAW([0xB7, 0x1E, 0x00]);  // CC Query Ch8
   310‚Üí  const response = await waitForResponse();  // Device sends current slot
   311‚Üí  await sendDAW([0x8F, 0x0B, 0x00]);  // Note Off Ch16
   312‚Üí
   313‚Üí  await delay(10);  // Inter-phase delay
   314‚Üí
   315‚Üí  // Phase 2: Set target slot
   316‚Üí  await sendDAW([0x9F, 0x0B, 0x7F]);        // Note On Ch16
   317‚Üí  await sendDAW([0xB6, 0x1E, ccValue]);     // CC Set Ch7
   318‚Üí  await sendDAW([0x8F, 0x0B, 0x00]);        // Note Off Ch16
   319‚Üí
   320‚Üí  await delay(50);  // Allow device to process
   321‚Üí}
   322‚Üí\```
   323‚Üí
   324‚Üí### Complete Read/Write Flow
   325‚Üí
   326‚Üí**Writing to a specific slot:**
   327‚Üí1. Execute two-phase slot selection protocol (DAW port)
   328‚Üí2. Wait ~50ms for device to process
   329‚Üí3. Send SysEx write command (MIDI port)
   330‚Üí4. Device writes to the selected slot
   331‚Üí
   332‚Üí**Reading from a specific slot:**
   333‚Üí1. Execute two-phase slot selection protocol (DAW port)
   334‚Üí2. Send SysEx read command (MIDI port)
   335‚Üí3. Device returns data from the selected slot
   336‚Üí

# Documentation Maintenance Guide

**For AI Agents & Human Maintainers**

## Core Principle

**When protocol understanding changes, documentation MUST be updated immediately.**

This is not optional. Outdated documentation is worse than no documentation.

---

## Documentation Update Protocol

### When Protocol Changes Are Discovered

**Trigger events:**
- New MIDI message patterns observed
- Device behavior differs from documented
- Parsing errors occur
- Web editor traffic reveals new patterns
- Firmware updates change behavior

**Required actions (in order):**

1. **Update `.ksy` specification FIRST**
   - File: `formats/launch_control_xl3.ksy`
   - This is the single source of truth
   - Add comments explaining the discovery
   - Update version history in file header

2. **Update PROTOCOL.md**
   - Add/modify relevant section
   - Document discovery methodology
   - Provide byte-level examples
   - Update version history table

3. **Update ARCHITECTURE.md if needed**
   - If code structure changed
   - If new components added
   - If data flow changed

4. **Update API.md if user-visible**
   - New methods or parameters
   - Changed behavior
   - New examples needed

5. **Create test fixture**
   - Capture real device data
   - Save to `backup/` directory
   - Document what makes it special

### Documentation Synchronization Rules

**These files MUST stay synchronized:**

| Change Type | Files to Update |
|-------------|-----------------|
| Byte format changed | `.ksy` ‚Üí `PROTOCOL.md` ‚Üí Parser code |
| New message type | `.ksy` ‚Üí `PROTOCOL.md` ‚Üí `ARCHITECTURE.md` |
| Control ID mapping changed | `.ksy` ‚Üí `PROTOCOL.md` ‚Üí Parser code ‚Üí Tests |
| New component added | `ARCHITECTURE.md` ‚Üí `API.md` (if public) |
| DAW port protocol changed | `PROTOCOL.md` ‚Üí `ARCHITECTURE.md` ‚Üí DawPortController |

**Rule of thumb:** If you read it from the .ksy file in code, it MUST match the .ksy file.

---

## Version History Requirements

### Every Protocol Change Must Document:

1. **Date** - When discovered (YYYY-MM-DD)
2. **What** - Concise description of change
3. **Why** - Reason for change (new discovery, bug fix, firmware update)
4. **How** - Discovery method (MIDI spy, device testing, etc.)
5. **Impact** - What code/behavior changed

### Location of Version Histories

- **`.ksy` file** - Top-level comments section
- **`PROTOCOL.md`** - Bottom of file, "Version History" table
- **Git commit message** - Must reference documentation changes

### Version History Format

**In PROTOCOL.md:**
\```markdown
| Version | Date | Changes |
|---------|------|---------|
| 1.1 | 2025-10-15 | Discovered control ID 0x40 has special behavior |
| 1.0 | 2025-09-30 | Initial documented protocol after empirical discovery |
\```

**In .ksy file:**
\```yaml
meta:
  id: launch_control_xl3_custom_mode
  title: Novation Launch Control XL3 Custom Mode Format
  ks-version: 0.11

doc: |
  Custom mode configuration format for Novation Launch Control XL3.

  Version History:
  - v1.1 (2025-10-15): Added special handling for control 0x40
  - v1.0 (2025-09-30): Initial specification from empirical discovery
\```

---

## Discovery Methodology Documentation

**Every non-obvious protocol detail MUST explain how it was discovered.**

### Template for Discovery Documentation

\```markdown
### [Protocol Feature Name]

**Format:** [byte sequence or structure]

**Discovery Method:**
1. Tool used (MIDI spy, web editor, etc.)
2. Steps taken to observe behavior
3. Data captured
4. Analysis that led to understanding

**Example:**
[Real byte sequence with annotations]

**Validation:**
- Tested with firmware version: X.X.X
- Date tested: YYYY-MM-DD
- Device serial: [if relevant]
\```

### Why Discovery Methods Matter

Future agents/maintainers need to:
- Reproduce findings if device behavior changes
- Validate against different firmware versions
- Understand confidence level of documented behavior
- Know which tools to use for similar investigations

---

## Common Documentation Anti-Patterns

### ‚ùå DON'T: Make Assumptions

\```markdown
// BAD
The control ID is probably in the second byte.
\```

\```markdown
// GOOD
The control ID is in the second byte (offset 1).
Confirmed by MIDI spy capture on 2025-09-30.
See backup/slot-1-2025-09-30T18-44-15-549Z.json for example.
\```

### ‚ùå DON'T: Document Speculation

\```markdown
// BAD
LEDs might be stored after the control definitions.
\```

\```markdown
// GOOD
LED states are NOT stored in custom mode configurations.
Verified by examining all 3 pages of mode data.

## Known Gotchas

### Control ID Mapping Exception

**Label IDs 25-28 map to control IDs 26-29 (+1 offset)**

This is hardware-specific, not a bug. Always use `mapLabelControlId()` when parsing labels.

### DAW Port Required for Slot Selection

**SysEx slot byte does NOT control target slot.**

Must use 2-phase DAW port protocol (see `docs/PROTOCOL.md` ‚Üí "DAW Port Protocol").

### Length-Encoded Labels

**Marker byte encodes string length: `0x60 + length`**

Don't try to detect patterns. Calculate length, read exact bytes.

### No LED Configuration in Custom Modes

**LED states are NOT stored in custom modes.**

LEDs are real-time only (message type 0x78). Don't waste time looking for LED data in mode fetch.

  let nameStart = -1;
  let nameLength = -1;

  for (let i = 0; i < data.length - 4; i++) {
    // Format: 0x06 0x20 [length] [name bytes]
    if (data[i] === 0x06 && data[i + 1] === 0x20) {
      const lengthByte = data[i + 2];
      if (lengthByte === 0x1F) {
        return undefined; // Factory data
      }
      nameLength = lengthByte ?? 0;
      nameStart = i + 3;
      break;
    }
  }

  if (nameStart >= 0 && nameLength > 0) {
    const nameBytes = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < nameLength && nameStart + i < data.length; i++) {
      const byte = data[nameStart + i];
      if (byte !== undefined && byte >= 0x20 && byte <= 0x7E) {
        nameBytes.push(byte);
      }
    }
    if (nameBytes.length > 0) {
      return String.fromCharCode(...nameBytes).trim();
    }
  }
  return undefined;
}
```

2. **Control label parsing rewrite** (lines 620-741) - Changed from 180+ lines of heuristics to 90 lines of length-encoding:
```typescript
private static parseControlLabels(data: number[], controls: ControlMapping[]): void {
  const controlNames: Map<number, string> = new Map();

  // Scan for label entries
  for (let i = 0; i < data.length - 2; i++) {
    const markerByte = data[i];

    // Look for marker byte that encodes length (0x60-0x6F)
    if (markerByte !== undefined && markerByte >= 0x60 && markerByte <= 0x6F) {
      const length = markerByte - 0x60;
      const controlId = data[i + 1];

      if (controlId !== undefined && controlId >= 0x10 && controlId <= 0x3F) {
        // Read exactly `length` bytes as the name
        const nameBytes: number[] = [];
        for (let j = 0; j < length; j++) {
          const nameByte = data[i + 2 + j];
          if (nameByte !== undefined && nameByte >= 0x20 && nameByte <= 0x7E) {
            nameBytes.push(nameByte);
          }
        }

        if (nameBytes.length > 0) {
          const name = String.fromCharCode(...nameBytes).trim();
          const canonicalId = this.mapLabelControlId(controlId);
          controlNames.set(canonicalId, name);
        }

        i += 1 + length; // Skip past this label
      }
    }
  }

  // Apply names to controls
  for (const control of controls) {
    if (control.controlId !== undefined) {
      const name = controlNames.get(control.controlId);
      if (name) {
        control.name = name;
      }
    }
  }
}
```

3. **Control ID mapping function** (lines 734-741):
```typescript
private static mapLabelControlId(labelControlId: number): number {
  // Special case: label IDs 25-28 map to control IDs 26-29
  if (labelControlId >= 25 && labelControlId <= 28) {
    return labelControlId + 1;
  }
  // Default: direct mapping
  return labelControlId;
}
```

meta:
  id: launch_control_xl3_custom_mode
  title: Novation Launch Control XL3 Custom Mode Format
  file-extension: bin
  endian: be
  license: MIT
  ks-version: 0.11

doc: |
  Custom mode configuration format for Novation Launch Control XL3.
  
  The custom mode data is split across 3 SysEx message pages:
  - Page 1: Mode name + controls 0-15 + labels
  - Page 2: Controls 16-31 + labels
  - Page 3: Controls 32-47 + labels
  
  Empirically discovered format through MIDI traffic analysis.

types:
  control_label:
    seq:
      - id: length_marker
        type: u1
        doc: |
          Marker byte encoding string length (0x60-0x6F).
          Length = marker - 0x60 (0-15 characters).
      - id: control_id
        type: u1
        doc: Control ID this label applies to (0x10-0x3F)
      - id: name_bytes
        size: label_length
        type: str
        encoding: ASCII
        if: label_length > 0
    instances:
      label_length:
        value: length_marker - 0x60
```

Key sections:
```markdown
### Control Label Encoding ‚≠ê

**Critical Discovery:** Labels use **length-encoding** where the marker byte encodes the string length.

**Format:** `[0x60 + length] [control_id] [name_bytes...] [next_marker]`

The marker byte range `0x60-0x6F` allows strings of 0-15 characters:
- `0x60` = empty string (0 chars)
- `0x65` = 5-character string
- `0x69` = 9-character string
- `0x6F` = 15-character string (maximum)

**Length calculation:**
```
length = marker_byte - 0x60
```
```

## 4. Errors and Fixes

### Error 1: Control Label Truncation (Multiple attempts)

**Problem:** Labels like "High Pass" were truncated to "Hig" or "H"

**Failed attempts:**
1. Only look for marker 0x69 - Failed: device uses multiple markers
2. Look for all markers 0x60-0x6F - Failed: too many false positives (ASCII overlap)
3. Check marker + control ID pattern - Failed: space (0x20) looked like control ID
4. Only detect marker + non-printable control ID - Failed: still truncating
5. Complex heuristics with lookahead - Failed: only 14% accuracy

**User feedback:** "Have you tried systematically changing controller names in the web editor and sending and retrieving the custom mode to and from the device via the web editor and diffing the changes"

**Fix:** Empirical discovery through systematic testing:
- Changed "High Pass" to "TEST1"
- Captured MIDI traffic: `65 10 54 45 53 54 31 60` (TEST1) vs `69 14 48 69 67 68 20 50 61 73 73 60` (High Pass)
- Realized: marker byte = 0x60 + string length
- Implemented simple length-encoding parser
- Result: 95% accuracy (20/21 correct)

### Error 2: Control ID Mapping

**Problem:** Label IDs 25-28 didn't match expected control IDs 26-29

**Fix:** Discovered +1 offset exception:

## Analysis Summary

**Web Editor MIDI Format (from spy):**
```

```typescript

```typescript
[0x20, nameBytes.length, ...nameBytes]  // CORRECT

    26‚Üí- Formal specification (unambiguous binary format)

    45‚Üí## Custom Mode Fetch Protocol
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí### High-Level Flow
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí1. **Device Handshake** (4-message sequence)
    50‚Üí   - Client sends SYN
    51‚Üí   - Device responds with SYN-ACK containing serial number
    52‚Üí   - Client sends Universal Device Inquiry (ACK)
    53‚Üí   - Device responds with device info
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí2. **Slot Selection** (via DAW port - see [DAW Port Protocol](#daw-port-protocol))
    56‚Üí   - Phase 1: Query current slot (6-message sequence)

## Custom Mode Write Protocol

### Overview

Writing a custom mode to the device uses command `0x45` with a different data format than the read response.

**Discovery Method:** Web editor MIDI traffic capture using CoreMIDI spy (2025-09-30)

### SysEx Message Format

```
F0 00 20 29 02 15 05 00 45 [page] 00 [mode_data] F7
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Novation ID       ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Write command
‚îÇ                       ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Sub-command
‚îÇ                       ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Command (Custom mode)
‚îÇ                       ‚îî‚îÄ Device ID
‚îî‚îÄ SysEx start
```

**Key Differences from Read Protocol:**
- Command byte: `0x45` (write) vs `0x40` (read request) / `0x10` (read response)
- Page byte followed by `0x00` flag
- Mode name format: `20 [length] [bytes]` (no `06` prefix)

### Mode Name Encoding

**Write format:**
```
20 [length] [name_bytes...]
```

**Example:**
```
20 08 43 48 41 4E 54 45 53 54
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ "CHANTEST" (8 ASCII bytes)
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ Length (8)
‚îî‚îÄ Prefix
```

**Discovery:** By comparing MIDI captures of web editor write operations with different mode names:
1. Captured write with "CHANNEVE": `20 08 43 48 41 4E 4E 45 56 45`
2. Captured write with "CHANTEST": `20 08 43 48 41 4E 54 45 53 54`
3. Pattern identified: `0x20` prefix, length byte, raw ASCII

**Validation:** 2025-09-30 - Verified with Novation Components web editor v1.60.0
```

/**
